newsitem.title: USA: World cropland productivity flattens - World Watch.
newsitem.headline: World cropland productivity flattens - World Watch.

text.p: At a time when world grain stocks are at record low levels, the increase in grain farming productivity has fallen to about one percent annually, well below the growth of the world population, the World Watch Institute reported on Wednesday.

"As the rise in land productivity slows, the world is moving into a period of highly volatile prices," said Lester Brown, president of the institute. "Either scientists must come up with a new generation of high-yielding varieties or population policymakers must quickly slow population growth."

Last year the United States returned to production most of the cropland that had been idled under commodity support programs for much of the past 50 years. But world carryover stocks of grain fell to just 51 days of consumption, the lowest on record, Brown said.

With reserves largely exhausted, the world will have to rely on gains in land productivity and crop yields to sustain the growing world population. But productivity has been growing at barely one percent annually during the past decade.
Japan's rice yields have been flat since 1984. Wheat yields have not risen since 1990 in Canada and Egypt, and in the United States since 1983, Brown's report said.
But in some other countries like Argentina, which is adopting policies that encourage investment in agriculture, the potential for raising grain yields is greater, Brown said.
